questions.question: Harold is a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) conducting an administrative investigation of a member of the cybersecurity team of an outside organization.  During the course of the investigation, he believes that he has uncovered evidence that may raise ethical issues.  The individual is certified by ISC2.  Assuming the canon applies to the circumstances of the situation, which of the following canons might Harold have standing under which to file a complaint?   (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: Under the terms of the ISC2 code of ethics, any member of the general public may bring complaints under Canons I or II of the code.  Therefore, assuming the circumstances apply, Harold may bring a complaint under those canons.  The question also specifies that Harold is a CPA, qualifying him as a professional and providing him with standing to bring a complaint under Canon IV.  Only an employer or contracted organization may bring complaints under Canon III.  This does not apply in this situation.

questions.question:
Carla's organization recently suffered a security incident where the attackers exploited a SQL injection vulnerability. As she reviewed the situation, she determined that the organization's incident response process was lacking maturity.
What business function should she focus on under the Software Assurance Maturity Model (SAMM)?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: Incident management, detection, and response are all security practices under the Operations business function in the Software Assurance Maturity Model.

questions.question:
Gavin is a software developer who is using external code in his own applications to simplify his work.
What term best describes the code he is using?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: Software libraries are reusable code that programmers can use to simplify their work.  It is possible that the library is either commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) or open source, but the question does not specify this.  APIs are interfaces to external services and they are not mentioned in this question.

questions.question:
Don's organization is having a difficult time tracking different versions of software being worked on by different developers.
What type of tool would best assist with this problem?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: The use of a code repository would provide a central location for the storage of code as well as version control to manage different releases.  Integrated development environments (IDE) are tools used to improve the efficiency of individual programmers and do not assist with collaboration.  Integrated product teams (IPTs) are a team organizational approach and not a development tool.  Runtimes execute code on a system and are not development tools.

questions.question: In object-oriented programming, what term describes a collection of the common methods from a set of objects that defines the behavior of those objects?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: A class is a collection of the common methods from a set of objects that defines the behavior of those objects.

questions.question: What database security feature uses a locking mechanism to prevent simultaneous edits of cells?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: Concurrency uses a "lock" feature to allow an authorized user to make changes and then "unlock" the data elements only after the changes are complete. This is done so another user is unable able to access the database to view and/or make changes to the same elements at the same time.

questions.question:
Allen is a database administrator who is concerned that users in his organization might engage in inference attacks.
What technique can he use to prevent inference attacks by presenting different data to users of different security clearance levels?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: Polyinstantiation includes multiple records in a table with the same primary key. Each record is designed for users of a specific security clearance level.  Aggregation is the use of multiple queries that summarize information to obtain sensitive information.  Provisioning is the process of providing access to a system or resource.  Referential integrity ensures that the contents of a database maintain relationships according to foreign key constraints.

questions.question: What software development technique includes as a basic principle that it values responding to change over following a plan?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: The agile software development methodology prioritizes flexible development that emphasizes responding to change over following a plan.  This is one of the core principles of the Agile manifesto and it is not necessarily embraced by the spiral or waterfall models.  The capability maturity model is an assessment tool and not a development technique.

questions.question:
Tom built a database table consisting of the names, telephone numbers, and customer IDs for his business. The table contains information on 30 customers.
What is the cardinality of this table?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: The cardinality of a table refers to the number of rows in the table, whereas the degree of a table is the number of columns.

questions.question: What stage of the SW-CMM model is characterized by formal, documented software development processes?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: The Defined stage of SW-CMM is characterized by the use of formal, documented software development processes.

questions.question:
Paul is evaluating a set of security requirements and determines that a mission critical application must be allowed to continue operating even if security controls surrounding it fail.
What term best describes this design approach?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: The <italic>fail-open state</italic> allows users to bypass failed security controls, erring on the side of permissiveness. In a fail-secure state, the system remains in a high level of security until an administrator intervenes.  In a fail-open state, the system defaults to a low level of security, disabling controls until the failure is resolved.  Failure mitigation seeks to reduce the impact of a failure.  Fail clear is not a valid approach.

questions.question:
Recently, a piece of malicious code was distributed over the Internet in the form of software claiming to allow users to play Xbox games on their PCs. The software actually launched the malicious code on the machines of users who attempted to execute it.
What type of malicious code does this describe?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: Trojan horses masquerade as useful programs (such as a game) but really contain malicious code that runs in the background.  Logic bombs contain malicious code that is executed if certain specified conditions are met.  Worms are malicous code objects that spread under their own power, while viruses spread through some human intervention.

questions.question:
Syed visited the desktop of a user who was experiencing system issues. He saw an error message that said his files were encrypted with a unique key for his computer and that he should click a button for further instructions.
What type of malware infection is Syed most likely dealing with?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: Ransomware's signature characteristic is the encryption of files using a key known only to the author and then demanding payment in exchange for the decryption key.

questions.question: Malware that does not leave any trace of its presence nor saves itself to a storage device, but is still able to stay resident and active on a computer is known as what?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: Malware that leaves no trace of its presence nor saves itself to a storage device, but is still able to stay resident and active on a computer is fileless malware. This is similar to a rootkit, which can be described as an invisibility shield. But its core features are that it interferes with low-level communications of the operating environment to hide itself and then hide other things, such as files and/or processes. A rootkit is usually deposited on a system as a file that is then executed upon system load or application launch. Cryptomalware installs a cryptominer on a victim system. Spyware collects information about the system user.

questions.question:
The internal development team has performed an assessment of the reliability, stability, resilience, and security of their newly developed business application. The code personnel who wrote the code were on the team that performed the live security assessment.
What type of evaluation method was used?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: This scenario describes a white box test, since those performing the testing are fully knowledgeable about the software code and its operations and functions. This is not lateral movement, which is when an intruder is able to gain remote control over another internal system after pivoting from the initial system they compromised. This is not passive reconnaissance which is gather information about a target in such a way as to not to be noticed by said target. This is not integration testing as it seems to have taken place in the development environment, as there was no mention of the new application already being placed into production. Integration testing is performed when a new product is deployed or integrated into a real or simulated production environment to ensure that all previously function work tasks still work and all newly added or expected work tasks work as well.

questions.question: A code developer is running out of time to complete a software project. The deadline is only three days away and several essential software functions are still not written. In order to meet the deadline, which of the following would be worth considering?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation: Code reuse is the inclusion of preexisting code in a new program. Code reuse can be a way to quicken the development process by adopting and reusing existing code. If there are software libraries that have code elements that perform the functions needed by the project, this can be a way to meet the project requirements and the deadline. However, third-party code could introduce vulnerabilities so this technique should be used with caution. Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) is a nonprofit security project focusing on improving security for online or web-based applications, mobile device applications, and IoT equipment. It is not a means to resolve the coding deadline issue in this scenario, but is a source of guidance of crafting more secure code of Web, IoT, and mobile applications. Normalization is a programming and management technique used to reduce redundancy, often related to database management. This is not a useful mechanism in this scenario. A stored procedure is a subroutine or software module that can be called on or accessed by applications interacting with a relational database management system (RDBMS). Stored procedures may be used for data validation during input, managing access control, assessing the logic of data, and more. Stored procedures can make some database applications more efficient, consistent, and secure. Stored procedures are an allow lists of existing software functions where users or other applications are limited to the pre-determined range of functions. Thus, stored procedures is not helpful in this scenario.

questions.question: What aspect of security governance is based on the idea that senior management is responsible for the success or failure of a security endeavor?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: The top-down approach is the aspect of security governance that is based on the idea that senior management is responsible for the success or failure of a security endeavor. Documentation review is the process of reading the exchanged materials and verifying them against standards and expectations. Control Objectives for Information and Related Technology (COBIT) is a documented set of best IT security practices based around six key principles. Abstraction is the process where similar elements are put into groups, classes, or roles that are assigned security controls, restrictions, or permissions as a collective.

questions.question: Which security role is ultimately responsible for due diligence in protecting a company's data?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: The asset owner is the person who has final corporate responsibility for the protection and storage of data. Owners may be liable for negligence if they fail to perform due diligence in establishing and enforcing security policy to protect and sustain sensitive data. The user interacts with assets and is responsible for abiding by company security policy, but is not ultimately responsible for company due diligence. The custodian is to follow the guidance of the asset owner in securing the asset, but it not ultimately responsible for company due diligence. The administrator is the IT operator who performs privileged tasks and must do so within the restrictions of their assigned responsibilities and security policy, but they are not ultimately responsible for company due diligence.

questions.question:
Threat hunting is an essential tool in tracking down and addressing threats. Examples of threat hunting include ethical hacking, penetration testing, source code review, and fuzz testing.
What type of threat modeling approach encompasses these examples?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: This question lists examples of threat hunting (a.k.a.  reactive threat management and an adversarial approach) which takes place after a product has been created and deployed. A proactive approach or defensive approach to threat modeling takes place during the early stages of systems development. Quantitative is a term related to risk assessment not threat modeling.

questions.question:
Mark's company has just signed a two-year SLA with a major cloud service provider. The company is developing a new line of product based on their own internally developed technology that has not been published or revealed to any external entity. A few months after the company has integrated the cloud service into their production processes, Mark receives an advertisement from a vendor claiming to sell a product based on new features never before seen. After further research, Mark realizes that those new features are the exact technology their company developed and maintained as an internal trade secret. Mark is confident that he knows where the leak occurred.
What is the basis of Mark's conclusion?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: This scenario describes a service-focused supply chain risk based around the insecure services provided by the cloud company. This scenario is not describing supply chain risk related to hardware, software, or mechanisms.

questions.question: Several bank customers have reported numerous unrecognized withdrawals from their account. An account manager has recently purchased a new car, is showing off flashy jewelry, and has been buying lunch for the entire department. In order to discover evidence of fraud and theft, which of the following could be used?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: In this scenario, mandatory vacation is the most likely means to discover evidence of fraud and theft. Offboarding is used to terminate an employee using a formal procedure, not for collecting evidence of violations. Gamification is a means to encourage compliance and engagement by integrating common elements of game play into other activities. It is more often used to encourage compliance rather than discover violations. A memorandum of understanding (MOU) or memorandum of agreement (MOA) is an expression of agreement or aligned intent, will, or purpose between two entities and thus is not relevant to this scenario.

questions.question:
As a member of the security team, you have been asked to collect information prior to the start of this year's risk management process. One of your tasks is to inventory assets and threats.
Which of the following represents a possible threat to assets within an organization? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: All of these items listed, and much more, are potential threats to an organization's assets.

questions.question:
You are evaluating the benefit of a safeguard to a specific threat. The asset is a customer database, which is estimated to be worth $10 million. The threat is an intrusion that could cause a 50 percent value loss. The attack has already been attempted three times in the last 6 months. The best countermeasure would be able to reduce the success rate to only once per year, but the cost of the protection is $350,000.
What is the benefit of this countermeasure?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: The benefit of this countermeasure is $24,650,000. This is calculated by first establishing the pre-countermeasure annualized loss expectancy (ALE1). From the scenario, we know that the asset value (AV) =$10,000,000 and the exposure factor (EF) = 50%, so the single loss expectancy (SLE) = AV * EF = $5,000,000. The ARO = 6/year (3 times in six months is 6 times per year). Thus, ALE1 = SLE * ARO = $30,000,000. The post-countermeasure ARO=1/year, so the ALE2 is = $5,000,000. The annual cost of the countermeasure/safeguard (ACS) is $350,000. Thus, the cost benefit is [ALE1 – ALE2] – ACS = $24,650,000. The other options are incorrect. (A) $5 million is the SLE. (B) $30 million is the ALE1. (D) $9,650,000 is AV – ACS, which is not a valid quantitative risk assessment formula.

questions.question: Which of the following is a true statement in regard to the selection of countermeasures?  (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management

choices.text: The result of the applied countermeasure should make the cost of an attack greater for the perpetrator than the derived benefit from an attack.
The countermeasure should provide a solution to a real and identified problem.
The benefit of the countermeasure should be testable and verifiable.
The countermeasure should require ongoing human intervention to manage deployment and configuration.

questions.explanation: Three statements are true: (A) The result of the applied countermeasure should make the cost of an attack greater for the perpetrator than the derived benefit from an attack; (B) The countermeasure should provide a solution to a real and identified problem; and (C) The benefit of the countermeasure should be testable and verifiable. The final statement is false. The corrected statement would be (D) The countermeasure should require minimal human intervention after initial deployment and configuration.

questions.question: Which of the following are goals of a security control assessment (SCA)?  (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management

choices.text: Ensure the effectiveness of the security mechanisms.
Evaluate the quality and thoroughness of the risk management processes of the organization.
Verify the cost-effectiveness of the security endeavor.
Produce a report of the relative strengths and weaknesses of the deployed security infrastructure.
Assess the risk and threats to mission-critical assets.

questions.explanation: An SCA is the formal evaluation of a security infrastructure's individual mechanisms against a baseline or reliability expectation. The goals of an SCA are to (A) ensure the effectiveness of the security mechanisms, (B) evaluate the quality and thoroughness of the risk management processes of the organization, and (D) produce a report of the relative strengths and weaknesses of the deployed security infrastructure. The other options are incorrect. (C) Checking cost-effectiveness and (E) assessing risks are elements of risk management in general, but they are not specifically part of an SCA.

questions.question: In areas where technical controls cannot be used to prevent virus infections, what should be used to prevent them?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: Educating users is an important part of preventing virus infections and works with technical controls such as anti-malware software. Awareness establishes a common baseline or foundation of security understanding across the entire organization and focuses on key or basic topics and issues related to security that all employees must understand. Security baselines provide a secure starting point for a system as a technical control. Traffic filtering is another technical control that can block viruses. Network design can be used to control the flow of traffic as a technical control.

questions.question:
You have been asked by the CISO to perform an assessment of the company's security training material.
What is the primary purpose of a periodic content review that you are performing?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management

choices.text: Establish new security guidelines for workers
Determine if the training is cost effective

questions.explanation: The primary purpose of periodic content review is to check for content relevancy. An assessment of the appropriate levels of awareness, training, and education required within the organization should be revised on a regular basis using periodic content reviews. Training efforts need to be updated and tuned as the organization evolves over time. Without periodic reviews for content relevancy, materials will become stale and workers will likely resort to making up their own guidelines and procedures. The other options are incorrect. (B) Content reviews are not used to establish new security guidelines for workers; that would be done as part of a risk management process or based on the results of an access review of worker user accounts. (C) Integrating gamification elements is a means to encourage compliance and engagement by integrating common elements of game play, but that is not the purpose of content reviews. (D) A content review is not the tool to determine if training is cost-effective. Cost-effectiveness requires evaluating effectiveness and judging training adoption and retention over time compared to security incidents caused by internal personnel.

questions.question:
Darcy's Doodles is an electronic content provider hosting websites related to art. The IT staff of Darcy's Doodles is concerned about the risk of an earthquake destroying their data center, which is valued at $8 million. After consulting with seismologists, they determined that an earthquake is likely to occur once every 50 years and, if one occurred, it would completely destroy the facility.
What is the ALE?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: The annualized loss expectancy (ALE) is the product of the annualized rate of occurrence (ARO) and the single loss expectancy (SLE). In this example, we first calculate the ARO as once every 50 years equals 1 / 50, or 2 percent. The SLE is $8 million, giving an ALE of $160,000.

questions.question:
Edward is helping his employer install software designed to monitor employee email communications through the organization's email server.
Which one of the following statements is correct?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management

choices.text: The company must notify employees of this monitoring when they log on to the system.
The company must notify employees of this monitoring before it begins.
Employees must consent to this monitoring in written employment agreements.
No notice or consent is required in this case.

questions.explanation: Court rulings have consistently stated that employees do not have a reasonable expectation of privacy while using business systems. Therefore, though notice and consent may be desirable, they are not required.

questions.question: Which one of the following requires that merchants handling credit card information promptly report security incidents involving a breach of cardholder data?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: The Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard includes requirements that merchants promptly report incidents affecting the security of credit card information. The Gramm–Leach–Bliley Act (GLBA) covers the customer records of financial institutions, whereas the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) regulates healthcare providers. The Sarbanes–Oxley (SOX) Act governs the financial records of publicly traded companies.

questions.question:
Ken's organization has several subsidiaries that share information across EU boundaries.
What mechanism could he use to ensure this information sharing is consistent with GDPR? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation: Organizations seeking to ensure that their data transfers comply with GDPR may choose to take advantage of standard contractual clauses or binding corporate rules. The EU/US Privacy Shield was a safe harbor agreement that would previously have allowed the transfer but that is no longer valid.

questions.question:
An organization is implementing security controls to protect sensitive data.
Which of the following choices identifies data that they would protect with additional security controls?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security

choices.text: Data posted on a public website

questions.explanation: Personally identifiable information (PII) is an example of sensitive data that should be protected. All the other options are examples of data that is accessible to the public.

questions.question:
A data policy mandates the use of watermarks on photos created by an organization.
Which one of the following best describes the reason for this policy?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security

choices.text: To enhance the quality of the photos
To support encryption of the photos
To detect the unauthorized copying of the photos
To embed hidden messages in the photos

questions.explanation: Watermarks can detect the unauthorized copying of documents, including photos. They do not enhance the quality of the photos, and watermarks are not related to encryption. Watermarks are visible, not hidden.

questions.question:
You are updating the data policy for your company and adding responsibilities for various data roles.
Which of the following roles is ultimately responsible for due diligence in protecting the company's data?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation: The data owner is the person who has final corporate responsibility for the protection and storage of data. Owners may be liable for negligence if they fail to perform due diligence in establishing and enforcing security policies to protect and sustain sensitive data. Users simply use the data. A data custodian is responsible for the daily maintenance tasks required to protect the data. A data controller decides what data to process and how it is processed.

questions.question:
Your organization has defined the data classifications within a data policy.
Which of the following data roles is most likely to implement data protection tasks based on the data classification?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation: The data custodian will implement data protection tasks for data. This includes performing backups, monitoring data for integrity, and any other tasks defined in data or security policies. Data owners have the ultimate responsibility for protecting data, but they delegate day-to-day tasks to the data custodian. A data user (or subject) accesses the data. A data processor controls the processing of the data, based on what the data controller tells them.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to protect the confidentiality of data on storage media?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation: Marking and labeling practices protect the confidentiality of data held on storage media. Erasing data or formatting media removes the data, so it doesn't protect it. Collection limitation refers to minimizing the collection of data but doesn't protect the confidentiality of data already collected.

questions.question:
The data policy in your company mandates specific procedures to eliminate data remanence in disk drives. It outlines methods to eliminate slack space.
Which of the following best describes slack space?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security

choices.text: Areas of the disk that don't contain files
Deleted files that haven't been overwritten

questions.explanation: Slack space is the unused space in a cluster. However, slack space can still contain data previously stored in memory. Clusters are groups of sectors. One way of eliminating data remanence is by overwriting clusters with random bits. However, overwriting a cluster with random bits does not create slack space. Slack space isn't directly related to files, even though files take up one or more clusters. Deleted files remain on the drive until the systems overwrites them, but deleted files are not slack space.

questions.question:
Your organization has several servers in use that they purchased from a hardware vendor. You just learned that the vendor announced that the end-of-life (EOL) date for these servers is in 60 days.
What does this mean?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security

choices.text: The vendor will stop supporting the servers after the EOL date.
The vendor will discontinue sales of the servers after the EOL date.
The vendor will disable the servers after the EOL date.
The lease of the servers will end after the EOL date.

questions.explanation: The end-of-life (EOL) date is the date when the vendor will stop offering a product for sale. The end-of-support (EOS) date, not the end-of-life (EOL) date, is the date when the vendor will stop supporting a product. Vendors don't disable servers that they sold to customers. The scenario states that the organization purchased the servers, not that they leased them.

questions.question: Administrators routinely connect to servers in the data center from remote locations using their administrator accounts. Of the following, what should be a prime concern when doing so?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation: They should take steps to protect data in transit by using encryption algorithms that encrypt data sent between their computers and the servers. Data at rest is data stored on media, but data sent between two systems is data in transit. Data in use refers to data in memory and used by a program. Data remaining on media after trying to remove it is data remanence, but this is unrelated to this question.

questions.question:
An organization is implementing a preselected baseline of security controls but finds that some of the controls aren't relevant to their needs.
What should they do?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security

choices.text: Tailor the baseline to their needs.

questions.explanation: Scoping and tailoring processes allow an organization to tailor security baselines to its needs, and tailoring includes scoping. There is no need to implement security controls that do not apply, and it is not necessary to identify or re-create a different baseline.

questions.question:
A hospital system includes several hospitals and medical centers spread throughout a geographical area. Their databases include a significant amount of information about a relatively new health issue impacting patients. Medical researchers have asked for these records to study treatments and outcomes, but the hospital system wants to protect the privacy of the patients.
Which of the following would be the best choice?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation: Data masking is a method used to anonymize data and protect the privacy of individuals in a dataset. It replaces privacy data (such as names) with incorrect data, but the dataset still retains usable data. Data minimization refers to limiting the collection of data, but it doesn't change existing data. Encryption makes the data unreadable. Although it may be possible to encrypt some columns, this would prevent the researchers from performing aggregation functions on the dataset to identify trends. Tailoring refers to customizing a set baseline of security controls, and it is unrelated to data anonymization.

questions.question:
Management is concerned that users may copy sensitive data onto USB devices. You're asked what technology will prevent this activity.
Which of the following would be the most cost-effective to implement?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation: Endpoint data loss prevention (DLP) systems can prevent the copying of any data to external devices such as Universal Serial Bus (USB) drives. A cloud access security broker (CASB) helps enforce security policies for cloud-based assets. Security information and event management (SIEM) systems provide real-time analysis of events occurring on systems throughout an organization but don't block activity on an endpoint device. Intrusion detection systems (IDSs) scan incoming traffic, but they don't block traffic leaving a user's computer.

questions.question:
Administrators manage several servers in your network. They are required to keep the audit logs for a minimum of three years on several servers.
Which of the following is the most likely reason why they must keep archives of audit logs for this long?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation: Record retention policies define the amount of time to keep any data, including logs. Data remanence is data remnants on media, and data destruction methods remove data remnants. Data collection policies define what data to collect, and often stress that only data that is needed should be collected and maintained. Data maintenance refers to the maintenance of data, such as marking and labeling.

questions.question:
Paul is selecting a cryptographic algorithm and would like to provide users with a high level of confidence that data, objects, and resources are unaltered from their original state.
What goal is he attempting to achieve?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: If a security mechanism offers integrity, then it offers a high level of confidence that data, objects, and resources are unaltered from their original protected state.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not a requirement for a cryptographic hash function?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: The output can be any length.
The hash function is relatively easy to compute.
The hash function is collision resistant.

questions.explanation: The output of a hash function must be a fixed length, not any length. Hash functions must also be one-way, collision resistant, and relatively easy to compute.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a valid security measure to protect against brute-force and dictionary attacks?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: Enforce strong passwords through a security policy.
Maintain strict control over physical access.
Require all users to log in remotely.

questions.explanation: Requiring users to log in remotely does not protect against password attacks such as brute-force or dictionary attacks. Strong password policies, physical access control, and two-factor authentication all improve the protection against brute-force and dictionary password attacks.

questions.question:
Kolin believes that an attacker is measuring the electricity consumption of a cryptographic device deployed in the field to attempt to gain access to encrypted data.
What type of attack is taking place?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: Side-channel attacks use information about a system's footprint, such as electricity consumption, to undermine the cryptographic system. Timing attacks require measuring the amount of time used to perform cryptographic operations. Man-in-the-middle attacks require intercepting communications. Replay attacks take advantage of authentication requests that do not include a timestamp by later replaying the message to open a new authenticated session.

questions.question: Which of the following is a true statement in regard to managing engineering processes using secure design principles?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: Security is more cost-effective when added after functionality has been established.
It's much easier to build security into a system during development than it is to add security to an existing system.
Security requires that functions and capabilities be minimized.
It is more important to integrate security into a solution for common or standard environments than for sensitive or critical ones.

questions.explanation: It's extremely important to consider the security implications of a development project from the early stages because it's much easier to build security into a system during development than it is to add security to an existing system. Security should be a consideration at every stage of a system's development. Option A is incorrect because security is usually more cost-effective when integrated early in development. Option C is incorrect because security can sometimes be a trade-off between security, functions, and capabilities but does not require that, in order to optimize security, functions and capabilities must be minimized. Option D is incorrect because it is more important to integrate security into solutions for sensitive or critical environments than into common or standard ones; however, programmers should strive to build security into every application they develop.

questions.question:
Zero trust is an alternate approach to security where nothing is automatically trusted. Instead, each request for activity or access is assumed to be from an unknown and untrusted location until otherwise verified.
What has been the major driver behind the adoption of the zero trust model?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: The primary driver behind the adoption of the zero trust model has been the proliferation of endpoint devices. An endpoint device could be a user's workstation, a tablet, a smartphone, an IoT device, an ICS system, an edge computing sensor, and any public-facing servers in a screened subnet or extranet. Being able to control, much less trust, all of these devices has caused the loss of a clearly defined security perimeter between the outside untrusted world and the inside trusted organization. This results in the "assume breach" stance, which requires organizations to "never trust, always verify." The other options are incorrect. Option A, advanced persistent threats (APTs), are a serious security concern, but they are primarily external entities attacking from foreign lands, so they are not the primary cause of the switch to the zero trust model. Option C, poor authentication technologies, are primarily an issue of choice; there are reliable and robust authentication options available, such as mutual certificate authentication and multi-factor authentication. Poor authentication is not the primary reason to adopt zero trust, since zero trust requires reliable authentication to be effective. Option D, micro-segmentation, is not a reason to adopt the zero trust model, but it is a core element of implementing the zero trust model.

questions.question:
Privacy by Design (PbD) is a guideline to integrate privacy protections into products during the early design phase rather than attempting to tack it on at the end of development. There are seven foundational principles of PbD.
Which of the following are among them? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: Proactive not reactive; preventive not remedial
Respect for user privacy—keep it user-centric

questions.explanation: The seven foundational principles of Privacy by Design (PbD) are: proactive not reactive; preventive not remedial, privacy as the default setting, privacy embedded into design, full functionality—positive-sum, not zero-sum, end-to-end security—full lifecycle protection, visibility and transparency—keep it open, and respect for user privacy—keep it user-centric. The other options are incorrect. Option B is a statement of the Clark–Wilson security model. Option F is the principle of zero trust. Option I is a statement related to "keep it simple" known as New Jersey style, which indicates that the quality of software does not necessarily increase with an increase in capabilities and functions. Option K is a classical security management approach that is replaced by zero trust.

questions.question: A constrained interface or restricted interface can be used to protect what security functions or benefits? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: A constrained interface or restricted interface can be used to protect integrity (such as the focus of the Clark–Wilson model) or confidentiality. Constrained/restricted interfaces do not protect availability, nonrepudiation, or proximity.

questions.question:
Your organization is planning a massive data processing solution rollout. The requirements are that the individual processors operate independently. Each processor will be assigned its own instruction set to follow. Each processor is granted its own memory space and bus pathways. The goal is to have over 3,000 separate processors working together under the management of a single master control and coordination system.
What type of large-scale parallel data system would be most appropriate for this scenario?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: This scenario would be best served by a massive parallel processing (MPP) system. An MPP is usually constructed of numerous AMPs linked together. MPP systems can encompass thousands of processors. MPPs are managed by a central coordination system. Asymmetric multiprocessing (AMP) systems usually have independent processors, each with their own assigned instruction set, memory, and bus. AMP on its own is not quite suited for very large processing requirements. Symmetric multiprocessing (SMP) systems have multiple processors, but they share a common OS, bus, and memory resources. Multicore, the ability to process multiple execution threads simultaneously, is often a key component of modern SMP, AMP, and MPP deployments in addition to standard single CPU systems. But multicore on its own is not a complete solution for this scenario.

questions.question:
Your organization operates a large complex set of web applications. Market research has revealed that a significant number of other business entities could benefit from some of the functions of your company's web environment. A project has been initiated to transform these capabilities into microservices that can be offered via subscription to external customers.
Which of the following are true in regard to microservices? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: Supports purpose-specific business capabilities through services that are independently deployed
Based on fast short-term development cycles (similar to Agile)
Crafted to host a single application, including only the OS resources needed, and sharing common binaries and libraries
Commonly deployed based on immutable architecture

questions.explanation: Microservices are often created as a means to provide purpose-specific business capabilities through services that are independently deployed. Often, microservices are small and focused on a singular operation, are designed with few dependencies, and are based on fast short-term development cycles (similar to Agile). It is also common to deploy microservices based on immutable architecture. The statement "Crafted to host a single application, including only the OS resources needed, and sharing a common binaries and libraries" describes containerization rather than microservices.

questions.question: ________ systems are used when real-time or near-real-time processing of massive data is necessary for a particular task or application. These applications can include scientific studies, industrial research, medical analysis, societal solutions, and commercial endeavors. This type of solution is composed of three main elements: compute resources, network capabilities, and storage capacity. Each element must be able to provide equivalent capabilities in order to optimize overall performance.
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: High-performance computing (HPC) systems are used when real-time or near-real-time processing of massive data is necessary for a particular task or application. These applications can include scientific studies, industrial research, medical analysis, societal solutions, and commercial endeavors. This type of solution is composed of three main elements: compute resources, network capabilities, and storage capacity. Each element must be able to provide equivalent capabilities in order to optimize overall performance. The other answers are incorrect. An end-of-service life (EOSL) is a system that is no longer supported by its vendor. Internet of Things (IoT) is a class of smart devices that are internet-connected in order to provide automation, remote control, or AI processing to traditional or new appliances or devices in a home or office setting. Grid computing is a form of parallel distributed processing that loosely groups a significant number of processing nodes to work toward a specific processing goal.

questions.question: The tendency for various technologies, solutions, utilities, and systems to evolve and merge over time is known as what?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: Technology convergence is the tendency for various technologies, solutions, utilities, and systems to evolve and merge over time. Often this results in multiple systems performing similar or redundant tasks or one system taking over the feature and abilities of another. Though in some instances this can result in improved efficiency and cost savings, it can also represent a single point of failure and become a more valuable target for hackers and intruders. Security governance is the guidance from entities such as a board of directors or steering committee to bring new insights, knowledge, and solutions from the broader world to improve the security posture of an organization. OWASP is the Open Web Application Security Project, which aims at improving web app, mobile app, and IoT programming security. Threat modeling is the security process where potential threats are identified, categorized, and analyzed.

questions.question: A small fire has occurred in the kitchen area of the facility. You look around for the fire extinguisher to attempt to put out the flames. A Type B fire extinguisher may use all <italic>except</italic> which of the following suppression mediums?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: Halon or an acceptable halon substitute

questions.explanation: Water is never the suppression medium in Type B fire extinguishers because they are used on liquid fires. CO2, Halon or an acceptable halon substitute, and soda acid are all suppression media options for a Type B fire extinguisher.

questions.question:
While reviewing the building's design and layout plans, you are concerned about the facilities support for security while balancing efficiency.
What infrastructure component is often located in the same position across multiple floors in order to provide a convenient means of linking floor-based networks together?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: A wiring closet is the infrastructure component often located in the same position across multiple floors in order to provide a convenient means of linking floor-based networks together. A wiring closet is where the networking cables are connected to other essential equipment, such as patch panels, switches, routers, local area network (LAN) extenders, and WAN backbone channels. A server room or data center are enclosed, restricted, and protected rooms where your mission-critical servers and network devices are housed. There is typically only one main server room or data center in a building. A media cabinet is where removable media is stored.

questions.question:
Recent changes in local policing patrols have resulted in an increase in burglaries in the general area of your business headquarters. You are considering several physical security mechanisms to improve the prevention capabilities of your facility.
Which option provides clear corridors for security guards to walk, provides for a means to sense when an intruder attempts entry, and will reduce the nuisance alarm rate?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation: A PIDAS (perimeter intrusion detection and assessment system) is a fence system that has two or three fences used in concert to optimize security. The space between the fences can serve as a corridor for guard patrols or wandering guard dogs. One or more fences can support touch detection technologies. An exterior fence is used to keep animals and casual trespassers from accessing the main fence. This reduces the nuisance alarm rate (NAR) or false positives. Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design (CPTED) is the concept to structure the physical environment and surroundings to influence individual decisions that potential offenders make before committing any criminal acts. PIDAS is to direct and obvious of a security mechanism to be an element of CPTED. A sensitive compartmented information facility (SCIF) is often used by government and military agencies, divisions, and contractors to provide a secure environment for highly sensitive data storage and computation. An SCIF is typically located within a structure, although an entire structure can be implemented as an SCIF. A main distribution frame (MDF) is a primary wiring closet of a facility.

questions.question: There are several models that are used to describe the methods by which network protocols operate. Those models include the OSI model and the TCP/IP model. In the DoD model, what is the layer number for the layer known as Application?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: In the DoD, DARPA, or TCP/IP model (a four-layer model), the Application layer is layer 4. In the OSI model, the Application layer is layer 7. There is no layer 5 in the DoD, DARPA, or TCP/IP model, since it only has four layers. In the OSI model, layer 5 is the Session layer. Layer 2 in the DoD, DARPA, or TCP/IP model is the Internetworking or Internet layer. In the OSI model, layer 2 is the Data Link layer.

questions.question:
A recent intrusion has caused growing concern in the executive group that the company network is not locked down sufficiently. Recent mandates have required that only unicast communications occur with IP and that IPv6 not be deployed until further evaluation. You have been tasked with performing network monitoring to make an accounting of all IP addresses actually in use on the local network.
Which of the following IP address groups do you expect to see in the intranet? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: IP addresses with an initial octet of 128–191
IP addresses with initial binary bits of 100
IP addresses starting with 240–255 when written in dotted-decimal notation

questions.explanation: In this scenario, the IP addresses that are expected to be seen would be Classes A–-C (which are also used for unicast communications). Class A addresses start with a binary 0 and a first octet in dotted-decimal notation of 1–126. Class B addresses start with binary 10 and a first octet in dotted-decimal notation of 128–191. Class C addresses start with binary 110 and a first octet in dotted-decimal notation of 192–223. Class D addresses, which are used for multicasting, start with binary 1110 and a first octet in dotted-decimal notation of 224–239. Class E addresses, which are reserved for experimentation, start with binary 1111 and a first octet in dotted-decimal notation of 240–255. IPv6 does not use class groupings.

questions.question:
TCP/IP is a multilayer protocol. Using a network sniffer, you capture several frames. There is quite a lot of information available for examination for each captured packet. You notice that most of the frames collected have several areas of expandible detail, which is due to the protocol stack supporting multilayer protocols that use encapsulation.
What is encapsulation doing to these network communications?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: Changing the source addresses of a packet
Adding a header and possibly a footer to data as it moves down the OSI stack
Protecting evidence until it has been properly collected

questions.explanation: Encapsulation is adding a header and possibly a footer to data as it moves down the OSI stack. Changing the source address of a packet is spoofing and is also performed by NAT in outbound packets. Verifying a person's identity is authentication. Protecting evidence until it has been properly collected may be called containment, but it is the responsibility of the first responder or the incident response team.

questions.question:
The CTO has informed you that a new technology is being deployed to link together numerous separate networks that are distributed throughout the organization's campus. These networks have not been linked previously because they support a wide range of protocols. The new linking system is able to address this concern through encapsulation and provides a high-throughput, high-performance network technology that directs data across a network based on short path labels rather than longer network addresses. This decision was based on the significant increase in efficiency compare to traditional IP-based routing processes.
What technology is likely being deployed?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching) is a high-throughput, high-performance network technology that directs data across a network based on short path labels rather than longer network addresses. It uses encapsulation to handle a wide range of protocols. This technique saves significant time over traditional IP-based routing processes, which can be quite complex. FCoE is used to encapsulate Fibre Channel storage communications over Ethernet networks and is primarily used in the deployment of a SAN. Software-defined networking (SDN) aims at separating the infrastructure layer from the control layer on networking hardware in order to reduce management complexity. SDN is not relevant to this scenario. Infrastructure as code (IaC) changes how hardware management is perceived to just another collection of elements to be managed in the same way that software and code are managed under SecDevOps. IaC is not relevant to this scenario.

questions.question:
Your organization has recently implemented an SDN to separate the control plane from the data plane. This should allow for greater control and flexibility over the network structure as well as greater access control over communications.
Which of the following models will the SDN most likely use?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: A software-defined network (SDN) typically uses an attribute-based access control (ABAC) model. SDNs don't normally use the discretionary access control (DAC), mandatory access control (MAC), or role-based access control (RBAC) models.

questions.question:
Mark is the manager of a massive warehouse used to store essential equipment for a medical provider. A complete inventory is needed yearly. Last year it took over three weeks to complete the inventory. Mark wants to implement a solution that will significantly reduce the time required to perform this important management task.
What is a field-powered technology that can be used for inventory management without requiring direct physical contact?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: Radio-frequency identification (RFID) is a tracking technology based on the ability to power a radio transmitter using current generated in an antenna when placed in a magnetic field. RFID can be triggered/powered and read from a considerable distance away (often hundreds of meters). Virtual eXtensible LAN (VXLAN) is an encapsulation protocol that enables switch-created network segments (i.e., VLANs) to be stretched across subnets and geographic distances. SSID is the name of wireless networks and is not relevant to inventory management. SDN is software-defined networking and is not relevant to inventory management.

questions.question:
Renee's organization has deployed her to an uninhabited region of the continent in order to research pollution effects on the flora and fauna in the area. She requires the ability to interact with the cloud services to record her research, and she wants to maintain contact with friends and family. She needs high-speed connectivity with minimal latency.
Which of the following will be the best option?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: Low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite internet service will be the best option in this scenario. LEO offers high-speed communications with minimal latency when compared to other satellite offerings. Geostationary orbit (GEO) satellite internet service would offer slower throughput with higher latency compared to LEO. Wi-Fi and cellular are unlikely to be available in uninhabited areas of any continent.

questions.question:
A content distribution network (CDN), or content delivery network, is a collection of resource services deployed in numerous data centers across the internet in order to provide low latency, high performance, and high availability of the hosted content.
Which of the following are true in regard to a CDN? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: A CDN is able to maintain customer demand levels of multimedia performance quality.
Using a CDN avoids straining individual servers.
All servers are data cloned and members of a distributed cluster.
Data is stored close to customers.
Client-based CDN can support high-speed file exchange.

questions.explanation: It is true that a CDN is able to maintain customer demand levels of multimedia performance quality, avoids straining individual servers, and stores data close to customers, and that a client-based CDN (aka P2P) can support high-speed file exchange (i.e., BitTorrent). It is not true that CDN servers are data cloned and members of a distributed cluster. Each remote server is configured to optimize operations for its local customers, which means each individual server of a CDN will be somewhat different, especially in terms of hosted data.

questions.question:
You are designing the network deployment at a new facility. The organization leadership wants to avoid issues related to internal network communication reliability that occur at the existing location.
Which network topology offers multiple routes to each node to protect from multiple segment failures?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: Mesh topologies provide redundant connections to systems, allowing multiple segment failures without seriously affecting connectivity. A ring topology is a single point of failure at any location around the cable ring. A star topology has a single point of failure at its center device. A bus topology has a single point of failure at its central backbone cable.

questions.question:
David wants to be able to manage the company web servers located in a screened subnet. The IT configuration currently prohibits an internal system from directly accessing systems in the screened subnet. Currently, he has to walk into the server vault to access the systems directly. He would rather have a secure connection to manage them remotely from his desk.
What should David implement?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: VPN from the private network to the screened subnet

questions.explanation: The best option for David to remotely manage systems in a screened subnet is to deploy a jump server. A jump server or jumpbox is a remote access system deployed to make accessing a specific system or network easier or more secure. A jump server can be deployed in the screened subnet to receive an in-band secure VPN connection, but most are configured to accept out-of-band connections, such as direct dial-up or internet-origin broadband links. A wireless access point (WAP) with wired equivalent privacy (WEP) is an insecure option because WEP encryption can be compromised easily. Telnet through the internet is also an insecure option, and it would open the screened subnet to attacks from everywhere. A VPN would not work in this situation since there is already a prohibition from connecting between the private network and the screened subnet.

questions.question:
The organization is using a NAC solution to cut down on unauthorized devices connecting to the network and reducing security compromises on authorized ones. The NAC is using a pre-admittance agent-based evaluation system. An employee who had been working remotely for three months has just returned to the office. However, after connecting to a known active network cable and booting, she discovers that her company-issued endpoint device has no connectivity to the company LAN or the internet.
What is the most likely cause for this situation?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: The device has invalid Wi-Fi drivers
She is using a personal device.

questions.explanation: In this scenario, the most likely reason the endpoint device has no network access is that it was quarantined by NAC. The scenario states the endpoint is company issued, so it is authorized. But with it being away from the LAN for three months, it is likely missing approved updates and required configuration changes. If these issues are resolved, NAC will return the system to the production network. The other options are not relevant reasons for the system's connectivity issues. Wi-Fi drivers are not involved with a working network cable connection. She is not using a personal device, since it is a company-issued endpoint device. There is no mention of switches or VLANs (although switches can be assumed to be present in most company networks), so VLAN restrictions is not as likely, especially since NAC was clearly emphasized in the scenario.

questions.question:
As the IT manager for a large enterprise, you have been tasked with upgrading the worker desktop and notebook systems. The CISO recommends using a system imaging solution to accomplish this operation more efficiently.
What security benefit is gained by following this suggestion?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: Eliminates the need for subsequent patching
Allows for all systems to be updated simultaneously
Blocks all future exploitations from external attackers
Ensures a consistent baseline across the upgraded endpoint devices

questions.explanation: The use of system imaging will ensure a consistent baseline across the upgraded endpoint devices, which is a security benefit. The use of system imaging will not eliminate the need to perform future patching. System imaging might allow for simultaneous deployment but that is not a security benefit. System imaging will not block future exploitations from external hackers. Only ongoing security management will potentially provide sufficient defense against future attacks.

questions.question: By examining the source and destination addresses, the application usage, the source of origin, and the relationship between current packets with the previous packets of the same session, ______________ firewalls are able to grant a broader range of access for authorized users and activities and actively watch for and block unauthorized users and activities.
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation: Stateful inspection firewalls are able to grant a broader range of access for authorized users and activities and actively watch for and block unauthorized users and activities. Static packet-filtering firewalls are stateless and do not consider context of the communications. Application-level firewalls operate at the Application layer (layer 7) and therefore do not evaluate source and destination address; however, they may perform stateful inspection of the packet payload specific to the Application-layer protocol it is focused on (such as HTTP for a WAF). Circuit-level firewalls are able to make permit and deny decisions in regard to circuit establishment either based on simple rules for IP and port, using captive portals, requiring port authentication via 802.1X, or more complex elements such as context- or attribute-based access control.

questions.question:
Cathy is installing a new VoIP solution that supports encrypted connections. She is also crafting the acceptable use policy and how-to guides for the employees to follow.
Which of these communication situations can be protected by the VoIP encryption?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: VoIP app to VoIP desk phone
VoIP desk phone to mobile phone
Skype caller to company VoIP solution

questions.explanation: In most cases, VoIP is only able to be encrypted between compatible VoIP solutions, which is usually only those products provided by the same VoIP vendor. In this situation, the only example that could provide a fully encrypted VoIP connection is when using a VoIP app to call a VoIP desk phone. But the assumption is both these VoIP endpoints are from the same VoIP vendor or provider. The other options will not support full connection encryption; either the endpoint devices will not support VoIP security or the features are from different VoIP providers. VoIP calls to a mobile phone or PSTN landline will not be encrypted. VoIP calls between different VoIP solutions, such as Skype and the company's VoIP service provider, will not support end-to-end encryption either.

questions.question:
Slayde is crafting the remote access policy for the organization. He needs to list all the methods of connection that are considered remote access by the organization in order to define rules and guidelines for each option.
Which of the following are examples of remote access connections? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: Using a modem to dial up directly to a remote access server
Connecting to a network over the internet through a VPN
Connecting to a terminal server system, mainframe, VPC, VDI, or VMI through a thin-client connection
Using a drop cable from an RJ-45 jack
Connecting to an office-located PC using a remote desktop service

questions.explanation: All but one of these options are examples of remote access connection methods. They include modem, VPN, WAP, thin-client, remote desktop service, and cloud-based desktop solutions. The only option listed that is not a remote access connection method is using a drop cable from an RJ-45 jack, which is a local-direct connection.

questions.question: Which of the following VPN protocols has always offered native data encryption?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: From this list of VPN protocols, only IPsec has always offered native data encryption. Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) is a proprietary Cisco tunneling protocol that can be used to establish VPNs. GRE provides encapsulation but not encryption. L2TP does not offer native data encryption, but it can support IPsec's ESP to provide encryption. PPTP did not originally provide native data encryption, but with the adoption of MS-CHAPv2 that feature was added.

questions.question: A ___________________ is the combination of hardware and software networking components into a single integrated entity. The resultant system allows software control over all network functions, management, traffic shaping, address assignment, and so on. A single management console or interface can be used to oversee every aspect of the network, a task requiring physical presence at each hardware component in the past.
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: A virtualized network, or network virtualization, is the combination of hardware and software networking components into a single integrated entity. The resultant system allows for software control over all network functions, management, traffic shaping, address assignment, and so on. A single management console or interface can be used to oversee every aspect of the network, a task requiring physical presence at each hardware component in the past. This statement does not describe wireless networks (there is no mention of radio channels or frequencies), private networks (this could describe an extranet, screened subnet, external networks, and cloud networks), or VLAN networks (there is no mention of switches).

questions.question: Which type of connection created by a packet-switching networking system reuses the same basic parameters or virtual pathway each time it connects?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation: A PVC reestablishes a link using the same basic parameters or virtual pathway each time it connects. SVCs use unique settings each time. Bandwidth on-demand links can be either PVCs or SVCs. VLAN is not a packet-switching technology.

questions.question:
John has been tasked by the CISO to help establish a new asset protection plan. Recent audits reveal that compromises have occurred due to a lack of adequate protection for sensitive and critical assets.
Which of the following would be an asset that an organization would want to protect with access controls? (Select all that apply.)
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation: Information, systems, and devices are assets that an organization would want to protect. Though not listed, facilities and applications are also assets that an organization would want to protect. Sessions are not assets.

questions.question:
Management wants to add a biometric access control into the main server room. They want to add a method that is the most accurate without being invasive.
Which of the following would meet these requirements?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation: Iris scanners are the most accurate, noninvasive biometric control from those listed. Though retina scans are more accurate that iris scans, they are invasive and can reveal medical conditions such as pregnancy. Smartcards are not biometric controls. Fingerprints are not the most accurate.

questions.question: Which of the following identifies a characteristic of a decentralized access control?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)

choices.text: It can be a single point of failure.
It always uses a single authenticator app.

questions.explanation: Administrative overhead is high in a decentralized access control model. Decentralized access control does not scale up easily and id does not have a single point of failure. It has multiple entities checking authentication, such as at every computer. Although a decentralized access control model may use a single authenticator application, all implementations of decentralized access controls would not use a single authenticator application.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes two-factor authentication?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)

choices.text: It requires users to authenticate with two independent proofs of identity.
It requires users to authenticate with text messages and a password.
It requires users to authenticate with single sign-on technologies.
It requires users to provide both a unique identifier and a password.

questions.explanation: Two-factor authentication (2FA) requires users to authenticate with two independent proofs of identity, such as a fingerprint and a password. Requiring users to authenticate with text messages and a password is an example of 2FA, but it doesn't describe 2FA. 2FA describes how someone logs on, but it doesn't require the use of single sign-on (SSO). A unique identifier is a username, and it is used for identification. A unique identifier with only a password is a single factor of authentication.

questions.question:
You want to ensure your IT network supports accountability.
Which of the following is necessary to meet this requirement?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation: Audit trails provide documentation on what happened, when it happened, and who did it. IT personnel create audit trails by examining logs. Authentication of individuals is also needed to ensure the audit trails provide proof of identities listed in the logs. Identification occurs when an individual claims an identity, but identification without authentication doesn't provide accountability. Authorization grants individuals access to resources based on their proven identity. Confidentiality ensures that unauthorized entities can't access sensitive data and is unrelated to this question.

questions.question:
Human resources personnel are setting up a new employee with a user account. They are also capturing the new employee's fingerprints as an authentication mechanism.
What is this process called?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation: Registration occurs when capturing an individual's biometric data. New employees provide paperwork, such as a driver's license and birth certificate to establish their identity. Identity proofing requires users to answer questions to prove their identity. The fingerprints will be used for biometric authentication, but capturing the fingerprints is the registration process.

questions.question:
Customers frequently return to an e-commerce site to make additional purchases. The company wants to allow customers to be automatically logged on when they visit.
Which of the following will meet this need?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation: The Credential Management application programming interface (API) will meet this need. It was published by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) as a working draft in January 2019. Service authentication refers to using service accounts to run services or applications. SSO allows users to log on once and access multiple resources. SSO isn't used for a single site. Session management is used to close inactive sessions.

questions.question:
New employees can choose their health plan by accessing a third-party website from the company website. When they access the third-party website, it automatically creates a user account for the employee.
What is being used?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation: Just-in-time provisioning creates a user account after accessing a third-party website. JIT systems commonly use SAML, but SAML is used for many other purposes. Credential management processes store credentials, but they don't create accounts. IDaaS provides SSO for cloud resources but doesn't create accounts.

questions.question:
An organization is using a cloud-based federated identity management system to share resources with several partners. After merging with another company, they decide to implement another internally controlled identity management system to share resources with the other company.
Which of the following best describes the identity management system after this implementation?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation: This describes a hybrid identity management system. They started with a cloud-based identity management system to share resources with partners, and the scenario doesn't say they stopped using it. The internally controlled identity management system is an on-premises system, and it was added to the existing cloud-based identity management system, creating a hybrid system. Session management closes unattended sessions and is unrelated to this question.

questions.question:
Sally has been hired by an organization, and the personnel department is configuring an account for her.
Which of the following must be included in the account configuration?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation: A user account must have an account identifier (also known as a username). Other information such as a full name, an email address, and the department where an employee works can also be added, but they are optional. Note that email addresses are sometimes used as the username, but not all systems use the email address as the username.

questions.question:
After a recent attack on your network, a security analyst discovered the attacker took advantage of a pass-the-hash vulnerability.
Which of the following has the best chance of mitigating this risk?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation: NTLM has known vulnerabilities to pass-the-hash attacks, so disabling it is the best answer. Enabling Kerberos or CHAP won't eliminate the NTLM vulnerability to pass-the-hash attacks. A pass-the-hash attack is an authentication attack, and NTP is unrelated.

questions.question:
An organization has an access control model that applies to all sales managers in the organization.
